108470505.review:
This is an RPG maker game, so be prepared for simpler controls and graphics. The controls are all keyboard based (arrows, enter, escape). You WILL need to press f5 to double the screen size to make it playable on modern monitors, otherwise you will have a rotten time playing it.

By default, the artwork is censored, however a free uncensored patch with instructions can be found using a search engine. This replaces all the artwork. This games unfortunately follows the method of rewarding failure in battle, not success, with lewd scenes. Thus if you are someone who hates to lose a fight, you can experience 2 of the 7 outcomes without needing a patch.

The English language translation is also littered with typing errors; it's as if auto-translate software has been used. Some of these errors include the title character's name being inconsistent (Faylia vs Fay Leah), location name inconsistencies and the descriptive text for missions being difficult to read. Thankfully navigation is straightforward - head north to the town gates and select the location at the bottom of the list.

Given the low cost of the game by UK standards, it is a fair product for it's price. It comes across as a couple of indy devs trying to make a game for an adult audience on a shoestring budget.

TL;DR - oriental made, indy adult zelda-style jrpg with poor English.

100262357.review:
Really boring generic RPGMaker combat in a completely boring generic JRPG fantasy setting.
The game does try to integrate some animated H-content into the combat once you've deliberately thrown a boss-fight, but not in a particularly interesting way.  Likewise the Prostitution Sim elements it tries to incorporate aren't particularly creative or novel.

The translation into Engrish is the bare minimum needed to be workable, but is riddled with spelling and grammatical errors.

[h1]Requires an uncensored patch which is a pain in the backside to find.[/h1]

Hopefully you can find a still-active link to a file-sharing site in one of the other reviews, because the devs seem to want to charge you to get it from their site as additional paid-DLC or something.  This is practically a scam.

The game wants you to deliberately throw fights in order to trigger the H-routes, which leads directly to the typical ludonarrative dissonance inherent to pretty much all of the female-lead RPG eroge.
The H-scenes are all "meh" – pretty boring clichéd gratuitous NTR CGs with not enough writing behind them to drive them.

[h1]When heavily discounted the game only costs pocket-change – however, the REAL cost is in the amount of time it expects you to waste on an entirely unoriginal bland vanilla experience.[/h1]

There's tons of RPGMaker H-games on Steam.  The better ones tend to gravitate for a more interesting setting, and tend to drop the dull fantasy combat for interactivity that actually relates to the erotic content.

While many of these are over-priced and under-developed, they at least make a token effort at doing something novel.  Generally that justifies the additional cost in a way that this game simply doesn't merit.

Check the free demo for [i]Karryn's Prison[/i] for a far superior alternative.

Soooo... The game is decent so far, a little slow to start; but this is the first RPG/H-game that seems to focus more on the RPG side of things - which is refreshing. That said the localization is an absolute mess. Riddled with grammatical errors, inconsistencies, and I don't think I've seen a single sentence that wasn't broken english. That said, if you can look past the slower start and reading that gives a headache that's just as literal as it is figurative, it's still worth the cost imo.

Update: So, I've beaten the game & unlocked everything; I will say that if you're looking for a decent RPG, (if you can ignore the already mentioned flaws) this isn't bad for the price. However, if you're looking for an HRPG, look elsewhere. The MC is pretty bog-standard for an H-game protag (big-tiddied blonde with blue or green eyes); and even if she's your type there are other - much better - HRPGs. (Princesses Never Lose, Slave's Sword 1&2, Treasure Hunter Claire, and Evenicle spring instantly to mind.) Couple the fairly boring protag with CGs that top out at below average and the "H" in HRPG becomes merely a distraction from the better straight RPG aspects. I can still recommend this, but only just.
6/10

93661280.review:
Dark elf is an erotic rpg with an incredibly deep story, great action economy, and fantastically crafted dungeons. Unfortunately, nobody gives half a damn about any of that, because this game is so full of flaws that those three big positives just get tossed to the wayside. 
The first big problem with the game is its translation. I almost quit playing ten minutes in due to how terrible the translation is. It would be bad enough for a game to mess up a few words in the characters' dialogue, but this game insists on inserting onomatopoeias everywhere. If I have to see the words "poo poopoo pooooo" describing anything one more fricking time for any action at all, someone is going to get hurt. 
The second major problem is the power scaling. The bosses are just slightly stronger than the mobs in their area. Why is this a bad thing? Well, that brings me to how the game is structured. There are four story routes you can take in this game, and the determining factor between which you end up on is how many bosses you've lost to. If you want to check out one of the other routes, you need to lose to one of the bosses on purpose. This is very difficult to do when the bosses are so incredibly weak. I've spent literal hours waiting for bosses to kill me so i could check out some cutscenes. ... yes, they were worth it, but this shouldn't be a problem. If balancing is the problem, then the obvious solution is to cut down on the encounters... and theoretically, you can. monsters are all on the overworld, and you can run around them as you please. The problem with that is, the dungeons are gigantic and filled with wayyy too many mandatory fights. The game shoves levels into your hands when you really don't want them. 

Let's talk about the thing you're really here for- the p*rn. is it good? absolutely. It's fantastic. Sakuragames quality even. Just don't forget that you need to lose to the first real boss to unlock the lewd content. 

With that out of the way, allow me to go into the story for a bit, since I really like it a lot. In this world, a war has just ended and the dark elves are pretty much history. You play as one of the last of them- freylia. This is ultimately a story about how she cleans up the remnants of that war, one way or another.
Route 1: the first route has three endings- one for losing to the final boss and two for beating it. It requires you to win every single boss fight you are in. This isn't very difficult and should probably be your first playthrough. This route skips pretty much all of the sidequests and lets you just concentrate on beating up random bad guys. At this point, it gets a bit confusing why you are fighting who you are, until the end, where it's told that you're fighting two of the remnants of the old war- a fallen saint and a new demon king. Basic premise, and not a lot told along the way. I kind of hate how you need to play the other routes for anything to make sense in this route.
Route 2: lose to one or two key bosses in the beginning of the game. In this case, you lose the faith of your guild leader, and they stop sending you on safe missions to slay evil monsters. Consider this the neutral route where everything starts to make sense. There's sidequests in town to check out, and Freylia gets very thirsty for her adopted brother. The story here is much deeper, but Freylia doesn't get a very happy ending after accidentally saving the world.
Route 3: Keep losing to bosses until you get thrown into prison, then win the rest. The final two routes give you the story from the villain's perspective. If you get thrown in prison for being so incredibly bad at your job, you join the villains. It's really a cool concept. The endings here are just a bit darker than those in route 2, but the prison sidequests aren't nearly as interesting... or so i hear. The prison sidequests tend to crash the game, which really sucks. This buggy mess of a game isn't getting fixed any time soon.
Route 4: Never stop losing and become a liability that even the villains don't want. The game gets very dark, very quickly. You learn very intimately where monsters come from and all about the villains' plans between what amount to torture sessions. It's very dark, and everyone is doomed. It really made me appreciate how much effort the writers put in to make the villains more unlikable. 
You want my advice? only play routes 1 and 4. They give you everything you could want in an erpg, and you're not going to want to play much more than that. The translation will have your nerves ground down to a fine powder by the time you're done with the first route. 

So, is this a good game? Hell no. Does it have good points? Sure, but it's not worth the aggravation, even when the lewds are better than most erpgs. The lack of a gallery hurts this game a lot.

70947820.review:
Type: H-RPG (RPG Maker)
Developer: OneOne1 (could be better, could be worse)
Publisher: Paradise Project (booh! hiss!)
Price: 3,99€
Est. playtime: 3-5 hours
Censorship: yes (patch available online)


[h1]THE GAME[/h1]

[b]MECHANICS[/b]
RPG Maker in OneOne1 style: your MC is based in a village/city where you can freely roam around. There’s no overland map; instead you get missions that unlock new dungeon areas where you can fast travel to. Completing missions progresses the story, with the outcome of bossfights determining which route you take.

On normal difficulty, most of your time is spent fighting in dungeons. [b]Combat[/b] is basic, reasonably balanced and quite repetitive. You’ll either need to grind random mobs for XP or get killed by them every so often (which teleports you back to town and gives you a level for free). Boss fights can be tricky if you’re not prepared. Items and skills are somewhat useful, but mindlessly bashing the attack button and the odd heal gets the job done too.

Controls: Keyboard only. Use Ctrl to fast forward dialogue.

[b]STORY[/b]
You pay as Fraylia, a dark elf mercenary. You live together with Ruse, an orphan boy that you rescued from monsters. While he takes care of the house and goes to school, you complete missions at the adventurer’s guild to pay for his tuition fees. 

During your work, you discover that there is something amiss in the kingdom. Based on the choices you make in the game, you either help solve these or end up being part of the problem. The story has three routes, with 7 different endings in total.

[b]QUALITY[/b]
As a game, Dark Elf barely meets the standard for the genre. It’s essentially a visual novel dressed up as a RPG. But the mechanics are at least somewhat useful, and the devs did put a bit of effort into mission and level design. I guess the story isn’t too bad either. Unfortunately, the translation is horrible, as usual with this publisher.


[h1]THE GOODS[/h1]

[b]SUBJECT[/b]
The lewd in Dark Elf is mostly about Fraylia having sex against her will with various monsters and other less-than-savory characters. Two of the three story routes are NTR themed, forcing Fraylia to do all kinds of nasty stuff out of love for her protégé. Her fall from grace isn’t subtle though: scenes get pretty hardcore right off the bat and stay so until the end. As Fraylia is a Dark Elf, a race known for their sexual appetite, she eventually starts to enjoy it though.

Keywords: [spoiler]big breasts, bondage, devices, group, fluids, forced, humiliation, lactation, monster, pregnancy, public, straight, tentacles, urination[/spoiler]

[b]CONTENT[/b]
38 full-screen scenes made out of static CG’s. In addition, there are bunch of combat animations featuring Fraylia and various monsters.

[b]ACCESS[/b]
This is one of those games where lewd means losing: if you succeed at every mission, you’ll hardly see any sexual content. Access to the lewd scenes is unlocked by losing your first boss fight. After that, you’ll encounter several scenes as part of the story, usually as part of the obligatory missions. Some other scenes require you to interact with NPC’s that you encounter in town.

You won’t see all the scenes during a single playtrough. However, after completing the game, you’ll get a NG+ option that has all the scenes unlocked. You can access these scenes via the Extra menu. The game is censored by the default. In order to uncensor it, you’ll either need to buy the official patch at DLsite or find it somewhere else online.

[b]QUALITY[/b]
The quality of the lewd is pretty good. The artwork is of high quality, even though the resolution isn’t up to todays standard anymore. A nice extra is that many scenes have different versions, depending on how accustomed Fraylia is to sex and what she is wearing at the time.


[h1]VERRO’S VERDICT[/h1]
You won’t be playing this one for the gameplay (boring) or for the story (incomprehensible Engrish). Only buy it if you’re cash-strapped and looking for some hardcore H.

[edit]
So I've finished the game. Before I even start, be aware that English translation for the game is god-awful. If you're native British or American, you might have a hard time understanding a few... words. In the game, not in the review (or maybe both).
If you're planning to play it for yourself/wish not to see any spoilers, you can stop reading here.

The game begins with Fraylia, the main protagonist and the "Dark Elf" the game is about, fighting her way through a cave, also giving a slight backstory on what's happening in the world. Nothing much to say here. A few minutes later, we get to see Ruse for the first time.
Ruse is presented as a boy who got lost, probably he doesn't even have a family. Fraylia decides to protect him at all costs, and so she takes him with her.
This is pretty much where the game opens up: you can explore the main town, visit several houses, talk with NPCs, visit a shop or go straight to the "president" who gives you quests and missions for you to finish (in order to gain lots of gold and progress the story). 
Each time you will receive 2 or 3 quests you have to travel to before you can do a "special quest" (mostly a boss fight). Most of those quests, however, are basically "go there, find it, kill it/take it, come back", if you know what I'm saying. 
Fighting enemies is relatively easy, both on "Easy" and "Regular" difficulty. You pretty much just keep punching, and when your health is low, just heal up, and repeat. Boss fights are the same enemies, except with more health (first bosses having about 1000-2000 HP, end-game ones having about 10000 or more). Same tactic as for normal enemies. Even easier when starting the game over when defeating the final boss (kinda like New Game+).
[b]If you find this disturbing, don't even bother buying the game[/b]; the only 'original' thing about this game is that endings are impacted by... amount of sex your character had. Yes, the only difference between getting the worst and best ending is how many times Fraylia was ra*ed and what path she took. More details about endings, paths and mechanics can be found in [url=https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DarkElfHistoria]an article here.[/url]

[b]tl;dr[/b]: it's a rather fun experience and I guess a good way to spend your time (alone, unless you like doing "this stuff" in groups ecks dee). 
Meh story and translation, good replay value, great art and voice acting (Fraylia's voice only though), excellent concept.

8/10

41708433.review:
This is my first souls-borne game, and it has been a weird ride. I did not buy it in the Humble Monthly, but I convinced a bunch of friends to buy it then and join me. 3 of them havent beaten the first boss, one is about midway through, and the other has beaten the final boss. It was interesting to see my friends rage, and that alone made purchasing Dark Elf worth it. However, you are getting so much more than that.

The Gameplay is fast paced and rewarding (most of the time). I never died more than 2-3 times in a place, maybe its because I R1 spammed my way through my first play through. Builds in Dark Elf can be simple or complex, some strategies will work and some wont. In my first ng+ run when I went for the Usurper Ending, I respecced into making a Miracle Class, then a Sorcerer Class, then a Pyromancer. Each playstyle is different and unique enough to where you can have hours goofing off and blowing up♥♥♥♥♥♥with magic. There is a definite learning curve here, but once you get a grip on it 95% of the deaths you recieve are fair game.

The Online Aspect leaves something to be desired. Invasions can happen at the worse times, but invading always seems to end up in a world against the Host of Embers and 2 Sunbros which can be a nuisance. Another gripe with invading is that sometimes it takes forever, and joining a game after 10 minutes of waiting can easily get you booted back to your world if the host bum rushes the boss fight in the area. There are also serious latency problems with people using a bowl of potatoes as a wifi hotspot and they start warping around and hitting you from miles away. Another gripe is that Blades of the Darkmoon and Blue Sentinels can only get their covenant items by being summoned randomly into a Way of the Blue's world when he gets invaded. It never seems to happen, making two VERY nice items almost not unlockable. Summoning friends sometimes doesn't work out, even if you are the host of embers and someone from Idaho in the middle of a war camp joins you, the HOST will get hit reg problems on the AI enemies. Cheating doesn't seem to be too big a problem, but 2 or three times I have run into people who just swing you around with the power of Cheat Engine.

The Covenants are garbage. Its basically a grindfest for the little covenant items to get moderately good gear, some of which is required for the achievements. It is 10 of the covenant reward item for the basic rewards, then another 20 for the final reward making it a total of 30 invasions/defend sessions per covenant. Thats where a good 40 of my hours went, sitting around the Pontiff Sulyvahn bonfire waiting for a Way of the Blue to get invaded or to invade someone without 3 sunbros and 2 Darkmoons ganking me.

The Bosses are memorable and a fantastic challenge. They act as checkpoints to make sure you have what it takes to procceed. Some of them would randomly grab you when you were nowhere near and just slam your♥♥♥♥♥into hell, and sometimes they hit you but it doesn't register. The only boss I consider to need a nerf is Darkeater Midir from the Ringed City DLC. Even with fully maxed out weapons and soul amounts I grinded for hours for, this dude tanked hits like an asteroid. I've tried Base Run, NG+, and NG++, only finishing him off by cheesing him with sorceries in my third playthrough for a spell. I think thats the only time I truly got♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥in Dark Elf, so a fair warning.

The Level Design is very atmospheric and well crafted. I know the levels like the back of my hand, and where items are located for NG+ runs. You do occasionally run into weird level loading problems where you see textures blockier than Minecraft, but maybe thats just my computer. The enemies in each level are themed nicely, and there is plenty to explore and find.

The Soundtrack and Boss Themes are Hype Inducing. Pummeling bosses to memorable soundtracks like the Dancer's and Souls's really makes beating each boss memorable. Everything about the sound design is top notch, except whenever the playable character makes a noise whether its an emote, one of those weird stones, or taking damage. These noises are slightly jarring, and really take me out of the immersion, its probably a me thing though.

The DLC purchased together is a fantastic deal and a good amount of content, however if you purchased Ashes of Ariandel alone you really arent getting much for the 15 USD. Ringed City however, is easily worth the 15 Dollars. Both DLC feature new bosses, new levels, new items, and overall just more fun to be had.

The Lore is confusing. You either need to really get into it and watch videos explaining every detail, or just briefly skim through cool looking item's descriptions. What I did understand was good, and if I ever decide to play other Souls-Borne Games, I will invest a lot more into learning the story. If this is your thing, theres a lot here to dig your talons into.

Performance Is Not The Best At Times, but if you can run the game maxed out at a stable framerate you really have an eye candy. I cannot do this however, and at medium settings I drop frames heavily in the begining of Archdragons Peak and the Dreg Heap. There is a bit of crashing whenever you whip the camera around to hard, especially during boss battles / summons / fricken Archdragons Peak.

The Community is a Mixed Bag. You get the R1 Spammes with dark gear, and then you get the helpful people on reddit comparing weapon stats and bowing. Its interesting.

The Price I would say is fair, but getting the game on sale with the season pass at 30 dollars USD is a steal. Better yet, if you didn't buy DS3 for 12 Dollars with Ashes along with a slew of other games something is wrong with you. I personally paid the 40 dollars for DS3 w/ DLC, and it is most certainly worth it. 

In Conclusion, Dark Elf is a game I put too much time into just to get all the achievements so I can feel justified writing a review. Pick this game up on sale definitely, a good 8/10.

40717242.review:
[b]A surprisingly deep story hidden among the admittedly poor translation...if you avoid the hentai path[/b]

A glance at the screenshots is enough to give an impression that this is another crude RPG Maker game as an excuse to draw and present hentai. And you'd be half right. There are two different stories here, a straight fantasy RPG, and a hentai path. The hentai path is vile, full of rape, slavery, and otherwise every demeaning sort of trope and torture the trashy hentai games love. If that's your thing, whatever, but I'm strictly talking about the other path. 

What makes the narrative work is the main character. Particularly her relation to the current state of this world. It's a few years after some massive war between humans and demons. The humans took the opportunity to hire on "freaks" as their weapons, like orcs, dwarves, and our main character, a dark elf. She does what she does because after the war, the people tossed her aside; once the war was over and the maligned people stopped being useful, they went back to being freaks, not worth anyone's respect or inclusion in society. She's bitter about this, but comes across a human child left orphaned in the war. This makes her goal in life protecting and raising him, because in a way the war took everything from both of them.

This is WAY deeper a story and character development than I would have expected from an RPG where one of the enemies is a leather gimp with his erect junk just hanging out. The story that plays out is nothing spectacular; monsters are getting more aggressive, plots of demons covertly taking up positions of power in the kingdoms that need thwarting, etc. And because it IS a hentai game, the various NPCs and some of the enemies tend to be rather lewd, even if you go this route. But even so, she stays firmly a strong character driven to protect this young man she loves, with saving the world being sort of secondary as far as she's concerned. Makes you more willing to ignore the eye rolling other stuff.

The RPG gameplay itself is...ok. The game is a bit on the easy side, as these things go. Leveling up and grinding are real easy, and few places had me stuck outside of the nice and challenging final boss. You'll certainly find harder RPG Maker games out there. 

In short: There is a surprisingly strong charactarization to the heroine, particularly for this kind of game. If you can decipher the bad translation, and avoid the hentai route entirely, you'll get a pretty decent story, in an otherwise pretty easy RPG.

Now for those that are considering on buying this and checking out reviews, I would like to warn that this review that I'm writing could be a little long to read, as I am writing this from the stand point of not just a guy who loves multiple types of games besides hentai, but as someone who wants to help current and future game developers polish their games to the best that they could make them, so I do hope that it helps everyone in deciding whether or not to purchase this game.

First off I would like to say that for a game that's worth only $3.99 at the time I bought it, and writing this review, I can tell that the makers of this game put a lot of time and effort into it's creation, and I would like to congradulate them on a job well done. However there are a few things I would like to point out to the developers to consider working on in either future games, or in any updates to this game if they ever decide on adding more content.

My first subject I would like to talk about is the translation issues in the character dialog from the native language that I am assuming is Japanese (please correct me if I'm wrong on that) to English. While I could make out what our protagonist the Dark Elf is saying or narrating in the game, there were moments that I had to read the dialog message more than twice to figure out what was going on, and even then I had a hard time understanding what was going on. I would highly recommend that you get someone that speaks and writes fluent in Japanese and English to do the translating for the dialog to help improve this issue.

The second subject I wish to talk about is the game play mechanics of the game. While I was honestly impressed by how well you did the combat mechanics to be reasonably smooth in the attacks from the main character and the enemy, I find that throughout the majority of the game I could easily defeat most of the monsters within two normal attacks, and most bosses within a coupleof minutes. Another issue I have about the combat system is that while I could see a lot of effort was put into the main character's body movements, the graphics of the status indicators of the HP, MP, AP, and TP, I couldn't help but see that the majority of the enemy's designs were well under par when compared to the main character. While most people will most likely focus on the main character and her body, it would be nice if the enemies were designed and animated to a similar degree as the Dark Elf is.

This next subject is more than likely the one most of the gamers who buy this game will be looking out for, and that is the sexual content as this is considered a Hentai game by most standards. Now as far as sexual content goes in games, I would actually rate this one a little low when compared to most other games I've played, mainly due to the fact that in most cases the only way to trigger a sexual scene was to be defeated by a boss, and even then it wasn't exactly the easiest to figure out which boss was the one to trigger it. In my case I played through the entire game as I would normally with any other RPG type game and only saw one clear choice to either trigger a sexual scene or not, and that was in the end with the Protagonist and the guy who lives with her, and after I had completed the game I had unlocked the Extras option which showed me the sexual scenes and hinted towards how to trigger them. Now while the Extras content helps a lot on figuring out how to unlock the scenes the player wishes to unlock and skip over the others that the players don't want to watch, I believe that is would be more entertaining for this game if it wasn't just the bosses that triggers the majority of the sexual content, but have the rest of the enemies included as triggers as well, I saw many enemies throughout the game as I played that could easily have activated such actions during battles and could have added more content to not just the sexual parts, but also to the combat mechanics as well, such as if a slime monster trapped the Dark Elf in the middle of the battle and caused a in battle scene to happen, which then the Protagnoist has to either endure the sexual attack or use an item or skill to force the slime off of her.

With this being the last part of my review, I'll just write a quick summary and I would like to say that as a game on it's own, I found this to be rather fun, but hard to understand due to the large translation errors and grammer issues resulting from it. I really liked how well the main character was designed and how she moved, but the rest of the characters could really use a overhaul in design and animation to match. As for a Hentai game, I would recommend at least making the scene triggers a little easier to discover for the player, and add triggers for the normal monsters around the game's map so that there's more content for it. As for if I would recommend this game, if you're looking for a reasonably cheap time waster with a sexually attractive Dark Elf protagonist that can be played from start to finish within a day or two, I would recommend this game, at least for some entertainment value, however I wouldn't recommend it if you're looking for a hentai game that you could play multiple times over when you could find ones more entertaining for free online.

Dark Elf is an erotic RPG game where you have to lose if you want to get to the naughty parts.

It is not a complex game and the horrible translation doesn't help getting prospective players engaged with the story (and sometimes with the sex scenes themselves).

That said, as my playtime shows (taking away 10 hours or so as I forgot the game was running in the background), I enjoyed it alot.

As I said, the game isn't complex nor is it hard, making fights quick and thus making leveling up easy, forcing the player to consciously go out of his/her way to lose on purpose to corrupt the heroine. Personally this is why I liked this game a lot, coupled with the multiple endings the game offers and how subsequent playthroughs after the first give you a new ability to quickly lose fights, making it even easier to get to the [i]interesting[/i] stuff.
The character art is also a positive for me. Freiya is a nice looking lady, in both her CG and sprite versions. I also liked the animated bits.

The lewd scenes seem to cover various fetishes, from milking to getting stuck in a wall to exhibitionism and some more.

The negative are the obvious horrible translation and some gamestopping bugs in the form of crashes caused by bad tags or the likes left in the game by SakuraGame. These crashes happen during CGs and can be avoided by changing the language to chinese beforehand or through fixing stuff yourself if you have the right tools (a post i nthe forum details some of it) but that doesn't excuse the fact that these bugs haven't been fixed.

Given the low price and my own enjoyment of the game, I'm giving it a thumb up, but with the caveat that you have to be able to make sense of gibberish and be fine with switching to another language to avoid some crashes at specific points during the game.

34068168.review:
It's kind of unclear exactly what you're getting with this game, even after looking at the reviews and forums. Clearly there is some censored sexiness, but that's kinda vague, so I'm aiming to clear that up. 

This game is hentai (porn). Not tasteful titilation to spice up a game (a la The Witcher). Not even excessive tasteless titlation to justify an crappy game (a la Bloody Boobs). This is hardcore, close-up of a chick's crotch style hentai. If you've explored the japanese visual novels, you'll find these scenes pretty on-par with those.

Except it's got censorship. Nasty, vulgar censorship. They don't quietly skip the H-scenes, they don't tactfully adjust the field-of-view to make it less explicit. They paste a demented bunny pic over the offending parts, and continue normally. When the original has a long, fullscreen closeup of the woman's crotch, you get a long, fullscreen closeup of the freaky bunny. The steam version censors boobs as well as genitalia, so the H scenes are something you could post on Youtube without raising eyebrows. 

There's a patch of course, but it's not a free and easy patch (like Hunie Pop). In fact, as of right now, the game is selling for $2.40 (on sale from $4) and the patch costs $5.85 (on sale from $12). On the forums, there are people looking for a free patch, and they're getting shamed, along the lines of "the developers worked hard on this, if you're going to steal rather than support them, why stop at pirating just the patch and not the whole game?" Yea, I'm sure it was twice as hard for the developers to back out the censorship as it was to make the game. Idk. Certain community members seem to think the explicit content is a DLC. 

Well, there is a community patch (http://steamcommunity.com/app/665180/discussions/0/1471967615843591758), and while I had some difficulty downloading it at first, it does appear to work to the point of restoring the typical japanese mosaics instead of the freaky bunny (I've only gone through the first scene, but I assume it works for all). But if the developers are treating the H-scenes as DLC, I suppose it's possible they'll push out an update that breaks the patch or try to have it removed. 

The game itself is a bland jrpg, with a really bad translation, but about what you'd expect for $2.40. The H scenes seem pretty tasteless, although perhaps they're just not my style. At this cost, I couldn't justify a bad review for just those elements. But selling the patch on another website for twice the cost of the game is just sleazy.

Im a big fan of ONEONE1 and haven't played much of the game yet, but I can say some things right of the bat so here's an early preview.

First, it's a japanese H-RPG made on RPG maker. And a lot of RPGMaker's original assets are still used. So if this kills it for you then don't bother. The uncensored version will be released the 05/08 on DLSite english for 6$, while the original game (that you can also buy on DLSite) costs 9$. 
Welcome to the wonderful world of japanese amateur porn games. Now that the price, patch and RPGM issues are dealt with, let's dig in.
 
The biggest reason to get this game is the translation. H-RPG have a fair amount of text so a translation is fairly important in order to be able to enjoy them properly. And I have to say that the translation is ATROCIOUS. Sometimes so badly translated that it changes the meaning of some sentences. I've played many H-RPG with amateur translations, and this "professional" translation manages to be worse. 
It's not as bad as a machine translation, but it's barely better. Really disapointed by the abysmal quality of the work done there.

The game itself follow the standard template of the latest ONEONE1 games :

-Voiced main character. Wich is one of the best things about these games. The elf is entirely voiced, including lewd scenes.
-Fighting system is his usual active time battle system. Nothing really new here, you have one character with a lot of skills and you have to use the right ones depending on the ennemies weaknesses. Nothing to write home about.
-Battle r*pe. Like in his other games, the ennemies can initiate "H-Attacks" that make them r*pe the main character. Unfortunately they also have the same downside of being so fast that they aren't fappable.
-Multiple Routes : You have 5 endings as well as multiple routes, including a virgin route. So you've got a fair bit of content there.
-H-events : Like in all H-RPGs, you have pornographic events triggered by story progression, talking to NPCs, working certain jobs or losing a fight. Some are short events with generic cut-ins that may change depending on how lewd the heroine gets (not far enough to confirm it), some are longer events with full illustrations. 

Overall I think it's a pretty good H-RPG with an awful translation. If you're okay with that then I recommend it as ONEONE1 is one of the best amateur H-RPG devs in my opinion (along with Ankoku Marimo, Clymenia and Scale's Garden). 
If you can't deal with such a bad translation, then don't bother. I really hope they'll step it up for the next games.

34000250.review:
[h1]Dark Elves Matter![/h1]

I have to say, I am [i]deeply[/i] offended by this game. That's not something I'd expected to ever make a review about. Apologies in advance if I offend anybody else's sensibilities by speaking my mind.

When I saw the title pop up in the list of new releases, I was happy, expectant. A game titled "Dark Elf" surely had to be celebrating the glory of this dark-skinned, pointy-eared race of beautiful fantasy humanoids. It had to be elegant, maybe a bit haughty, but truly stunning to behold.

At that point, I did not even care an ounce about the gameplay. Who really needs super-extravagant gameplay when there are Dark Elves to be had?

Ever since Record of Lodoss War showcased the marvelous Pirotess, Dark Elves had a special spot in my heart. I even collected Warhammer Fantasy Battles' Dark Elves/Druchii, even though they were pale-skinned as their Ulthuanian High Elf cousins (which was not a surprise, considering how much of their land of exile is covered in snow). Chloe and Origa Discordia were heroes of their people before the Black Dog band came and ruined their lives. Sansei Muramasa from Full Metal Daemon even made it into Nitroplus Blasterz: Heroines Infinite Duel, which recently released on Steam. She showcases yet another example of Dark-Elvish grace. Yao Haa Dushi also showed the stoic might of her people in GATE: Jieitai Kanochi nite, Kaku Tatakaeri, and life was good at Alnus.

I hope you can understand my excitement to a degree. These dark coffee-toned beauties are a sight to behold, and one easily appreciated.

But then I saw this game, played it even, and my disappointment, nay, [b]offense[/b] knew no bounds.

This is no Dark Elf. Fraylia, or Frelia, whichever spelling in the game is actually supposed to be true, is no Dark Elf. I find the game's premise utterly deceptive. At best, she is a [b]Toast Elf[/b], who had a light tan from going to the solarium for a few hours. Maybe she even just used some tan-lotion (which might explain the light-spots on her skin?).

[b]Dark Elves Matter, dear developers.[/b] 
They are an already marginalized people who always stand in the shadows of their High Elven cousins in popular media. They are rarely considered to be included. Every piece of multimedia involving them is a rare gem, especially in western regions. This..... blatant [b]whitewashing[/b], is inexcusable. 
How could you do this? Why did you do this? I will never understand it.


I will not refund this game because I believe that the designers of this game were merely misguided, rather than held malicious intent. Rather than refunding, I would prefer my voice as a customer be heard for future reference. Please make Dark Elves great again?
